thread.title: US stocks end higher, keeping alive positive momentum
thread.title_full: US stocks end higher, keeping alive positive momentum

title: US stocks end higher, keeping alive positive momentum
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 12, 2015, 21:53 BST - UK Markets closed US stocks end higher, keeping alive positive momentum AFP â€“ 9 minutes ago View Photo 

US stocks finished higher Monday, keeping alive the positive momentum from last week's rally despite weakness in petroleum-linked shares. 
The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 47.37 points (0.28 percent) to 17,131.86. 
The broad-based S&P 500 rose 2.57 (0.13 percent) to 2,017.46, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index added 8.17 (0.17 percent) at 4,838.64. 
Analysts said volume was light due to the Columbus Day holiday in the US, a government holiday that shut the treasury market. 
The S&P 500 gained 3.26 percent last week to post its biggest weekly gain since December 2014. 
"It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) 's not very exciting," said Michael James, managing director at Wedbush Securities. "It's more about people digesting the pretty good move in the market last week that caught a lot of people by surprise." 
Petroleum-linked stocks dropped following a big decline in oil prices. Dow member Chevron (Swiss: CVX.SW - news ) lost 0.9 percent, Schlumberger (LSE: 0CT7.L - news ) fell 1.9 percent and Apache (NYSE: APA - news ) dropped 3.3 percent. 
Data-storage giant EMC (Taiwan OTC: 5299.TWO - news ) rose 1.8 percent on news it will be acquired for $67 billion by privately held Dell, which aims to position itself as a leader in cloud computing and other growing technology businesses 
VMware (NYSE: VMW - news ) , a cloud infrastructure company of which EMC holds about 80 percent, fell 8.1 percent. Dell said VMware would remain an independent, publicly-traded company. 
Drugmaker Eli Lilly slumped 7.8 percent on news it has terminated a trial of its cardiovascular disease treatment evacetrapib for lack of effectiveness. 
Airline stocks were higher, with American Airlines (Xetra: A1G.DE - news ) rising 3.4 percent, Delta Air Lines (NYSE: DAL - news ) 2.7 percent and United Continental (NYSE: UAL - news ) 3.8 percent. Delta is scheduled to report earnings on Wednesday. 
Microblogging company Twitter (Xetra: A1W6XZ - news ) fell 6.8 percent, giving back some of the gains since last Monday's announcement that interim head Jack Dorsey would stay on as chief executive. Twitter reportedly plans staff layoffs this week. 
Other companies with larger gains included Chinese Internet giant Alibaba (+2.3 percent), Amazon (+1.9 percent) and Priceline (+2.6 percent). 
A heavy earnings schedule this week includes reports from JPMorgan Chase (Swiss: JPM.SW - news ) and General Electric.
